unit: Unit 8 | Inference for Categorical Data: Chi-Square
title: Chi-Squared GOF Test
question_text:
The vegetable sales at a local convenience store last year broke down as follows: $34\%$ broccoli, $21\%$ peas, $18\%$ carrots, $17\%$ cabbage, and $10\%$ beans.
Recently a random sample of $123$ vegetable-buying customers found that $39$ bought broccoli, $23$ bought peas, $20$ bought carrots, $17$ bought cabbage, and $24$ bought beans. A chi-squared goodness of fit test was performed.
Determine the test statistic, $p$-value, and degrees of freedom.

choices.text:
Test statistic: $12.57$
$P$-value:$ p < 0.0005$
Degrees of freedom: $4$

solution:
First, find the expected counts:

Broccoli: $123\cdot 0.34 = 41.82$
Peas: $123\cdot 0.21 = 25.83 $
Carrots: $123\cdot 0.18 = 22.14$
Cabbage: $123\cdot 0.17 = 20.91$
Beans: $123\cdot 0.1 = 12.3$

The test statistic can be found using the following formula:

$$\dfrac{(39-41.82)^2}{41.82}+\dfrac{(23-25.83)^2}{25.83}+\dfrac{(20-22.14)^2}{22.14}+\dfrac{(17-20.91)^2}{20.91}+\dfrac{(24-12.3)^2}{12.3}$$

$$= 0.19+0.31+0.21+0.73+11.13 = 12.57$$

With $5$ proportions, degrees of freedom are $5-1 = 4$.

The $p$-value using the chi-squared chart is between $1\%$ and $2\%$.

Thus, the correct answer is Choice 'C'.
